As NYC‚Äôs LL97 gets underway, it is arguably the biggest driver of building decarbonization in any city nationwide. The law aims to reduce building emissions by 40 percent by 2030 and 80 percent by 2050, particularly focusing on the city's largest buildings. Today, multiple states and cities have adopted building performance standard policies, including Maryland, Massachusetts, and others. With many developers and building owners facing increasing pressure to reduce carbon emissions, more cities and states expect similar policies to help reach net-zero building emissions by 2050. For those developers and building owners beginning to explore building decarbonization and compliance, the options can be overwhelming, from financials to ensuring actions align with objectives. Brightcore Energy has helped many building owners bring their properties into compliance, helping them achieve their financial, sustainability, and decarbonization objectives. Collaboration between commercial landlords and tenants is crucial to meeting NYC's ambitious Local Law 97 (LL97) emissions targets. Urban Green Council's recently released guide, "Four Opportunities to Align Commercial Landlords and Tenants for LL97 Performance," offers a comprehensive look at achieving this alignment effectively. Throughout this informative strategic publication, the piece delves into four strategic areas seeking to better align commercial landlord and tenant energy management to meet LL97 requirements. These include emphasizing the importance of educating tenants to promote voluntary engagement and addressing the need for market adaptation of commercial leases that reflect the new energy efficiency requirements. Additionally, the publication provides significant guidance and insight on navigating the complex data landscape, ensuring that building owners and service providers can collect and interpret data accurately for compliance and support LL97 efforts. As an indispensable resource for building owners, developers, and related stakeholders, this guide is an excellent growth point for decarbonizing the built environment with actionable recommendations to align landlord and tenant interests. Read more here: https://hubs.ly/Q02JDKD20. #Sustainability #GreenBuilding #LL97 #ClimateAction #EnergyEfficiency #BuildingDecarbonization #NYC #CommercialRealEstate

üè¢ This month NYC Department of Buildings issued a change in Local Law 97: Building owners who can show a good faith effort toward reducing emissions will get a two-year grace period on carbon fines. The move came after many condo and co-op associations complained that they could not line up financing in time for the January 2024 deadline to make the necessary retrofits, the Commercial Observer reported. üåû The good news There's progress. The city expected that 80% of buildings required to be compliant would meet the standards for LL97. And so far 89% of properties met the city's energy goals this year, the DOB stated. But, that still leaves about 1,500 buildings (some of which are the city's largest skyscrapers) with a ton of work to do in order to avoid LL97 fines, the Commercial Observer reported. üñºÔ∏è The big picture Delaying action means there will be steeper emissions cuts required down the line to meet long-term goals. The earlier, the better. One of our favorite Substack newsletters, Sustainability by the Numbers written by Hannah Ritchie doubles down on this idea: Yes, the upfront costs for technology needed to reduce emissions might be cheaper further down the road. However, "over the medium- to long-term, it's a different story. These investments pay back through reduced fuel costs and efficiency gains such that acting early saves money," writes Ritchie. ‚¨áÔ∏è The bottom line "My advice to building owners and operators: don't delay, because adopting the proper technology to increase the operational efficiency of your assets takes time," writes Brendan Wallace, co-founder and managing partner of Fifth Wall. "There's existing technology you can implement now that saves you money by both avoiding fines and reducing energy bills." #realestate #climate #locallaw97
